unnormalised: ## The Curious Case of the Missing PNR
normalised: ## The Curious Case of the Missing P-N-R

unnormalised: Ever booked a train ticket and felt like the PNR number was playing hide-and-seek? You’re not alone! It’s happened to the best of us, even my dear chacha, Rakesh. He's generally as organized as a government file cabinet (read: not very), but even he felt bamboozled when his IRCTC ticket confirmation mysteriously vanished moments before his trip to Jaipur. He started shouting, "Where's my PNR!?" like he'd lost his dentures at a wedding.
normalised: Ever booked a train ticket and felt like the P-N-R number was playing hide-and-seek? You’re not alone! It’s happened to the best of us, even my dear chacha, Rakesh. He's generally as organized as a government file cabinet (read: not very), but even he felt bamboozled when his I-R-C-T-C ticket confirmation mysteriously vanished moments before his trip to Jaipur. He started shouting, "Where's my P-N-R!?" like he'd lost his dentures at a wedding.

unnormalised: The panic was real. He was convinced he’d imagined the entire trip. Visions of missing his train, facing his wife's wrath for wasting money, and sleeping on a bench at New Delhi Railway Station haunted him. It was a full-blown Bollywood drama, only instead of a kidnapped heroine, it was a 10-digit alphanumeric code: 4932875610.

unnormalised: Then there's my friend, Priya. She’s usually Ms. Efficient, but even she once nearly missed her flight because she accidentally typed “PNR” into Google instead of her actual PNR. Imagine the scene: she rocks up to the IndiGo counter at the last minute, flustered and waving her phone like a frantic conductor, only to be told, "Madam, that's not a PNR, that's a search query!" Her actual PNR was hidden in a WhatsApp message from her travel agent, a travel agency with the code 6E337, buried under a mountain of forwarded jokes.

Her actual P-N-R was hidden in a WhatsApp message from her travel agent, a travel agency with the code six E three three seven, buried under a mountain of forwarded jokes.

unnormalised: The airlines aren’t always angels either. Sometimes they send confirmation emails that look like spam – all flashing banners and hidden fine print. You're more likely to spot a unicorn than find your 6-character alphanumeric booking reference, like say D8YR7S. And let's not forget the websites that generate auto-assigned booking IDs that look like random gibberish; trying to make sense of an IXIGO reference no. like "IX-2024-BLR-DEL-34567" can feel like deciphering ancient Sanskrit.

unnormalised: Ultimately, the hunt for your PNR number, flight reference, or even a simple ticket ID is a shared human experience, filled with frustration, momentary despair, and, occasionally, the sweet relief of finding it lurking in the unlikeliest of places. Next time you find yourself searching for that elusive code, take a deep breath, check your spam folder, and maybe, just maybe, ask your chacha for help. After all, he’s a professional at losing (and eventually finding) things.
